full_conversation:
Seeker: So I'm trying to convince my father who's 87 years old that he needs to use a walker or a wheelchair to get around. Because without that, he's always at risk of falling and injuring himself severely. My dad is very stubborn. He doesn't want to be told what to do and he doesn't want to feel like he's dependent. So how to convince him to use a walker or the wheelchair is a situation that I'm currently dealing with, that's giving me a lot of frustration.

Supporter: You need to talk to your father from a place of understanding, and let him know that you understand how hard it is to give up the freedoms he's enjoyed his entire life. However, he also has a very loving family that is very worried about him, and doesn't want to see him fall and get hurt (or worse). Tell him that him using a walker isn't so much about loosing his independence, it's easing the worries of those who care about him.

full_conversation:
Seeker: I had a professional, moral problem. I was in upper management and I found out that the company was about to be sold. A lot of people were gonna lose their jobs. But I was told that if I kept my mouth shut and stayed until the sale, I would get an 80% a bonus from my salary. I lived with it for as long as I could. And then I found them starting to really employ, uh, refer to the employees as numbers in departments instead of as individuals. And that went a little too far with me. I knew that they were going to eliminate whole departments of good people and they wanted to blindside them. I couldn't allow that to happen. I decided to risk the 80% bonus and I started teaching people how to do their, uh, resume so that they can apply for another job. I also help people get other jobs in the end. I did stay until the sale. I did get my 80% bonus. They were very upset that I was telling the employees, but I was in such a position that it was a catch 22 for them. If they got rid of me, then everybody was gonna find out anyway. And if they kept me that maybe the, the place would keep running until the cell shortly after the sale, 90% of all the employees were terminated. I retired at 60 a half. So it cost me quite a few years of income. But in the end I'm satisfied with what I did.

Supporter: That's a really tough situation, and not a lot of people would have responded the same way you did. You did the right thing. You helped a lot of people, even though it was stressful for you, since you weren't sure if you'd get fired and/or lose the bonus. You did a good thing.

My relationship with my ex wasn't the best but not. Well, sometimes it was, we were together for 9.5 years and I don't know what to do to try to be with her again or to see somebody else, which will, which causes me a lot of anxiety. Uh I don't like meeting other people. So now I'm just stuck and there's no one to really talk to it about because everyone will just say not to go back with my ex. She moved out now I'm all alone and it is very lonely, but I felt lonely with her for years because something changed about her. But since she broke up and when we hang out once a week, she seems like how she used to be. She seems great. Maybe we just shouldn't live together. It's a lot of things to think about and I don't know what the right answer is. Either way. I'm very unhappy. I don't know what to do about it.

Seeker: So I'm um in this position at work where as part of my job, I help with the hiring process. And at this time, one of the openings happens to be the role for my boss and um my grand boss who's helping me with it is pretty new to the company. So he doesn't, he's not really familiar with our processes and we have a couple internal candidates. Um They're both colleagues of mine. One of them I would love to see in the role, one of them not so good and my grand boss because he's new, he doesn't really know of the history and I need to stay neutral. Um Well, also I don't want him to uh fill this role with somebody who would not um who has kind of a negative history with the company. And then there's also, you know, it's probably not even going the position, probably won't even go to either of my colleagues. Um There's a chance that my grand boss wants to bring somebody that he has a history with from outside the company that he wants to make it look like it's um an objective, um you know, fair process where we're considering everybody. And then I, um you know, and then the weird thing is, you know, this person that I'm helping through this um recruitment process, they'll end up being my boss. So whatever impression they have of me throughout this, um I'll be reporting to them.

The problem is that I have a disability that affects my mobility. And if I move to this other house, I will have to go up some very steep stairs to get to my room and that will be very difficult for me. I also need to do major renovations on several rooms in that house before it'll be liable for me. And that will cost me thousands and thousands of dollars. And I'm living on a limited budget right now. If I go ahead and do this and use all that money to make the repairs to the other house, I could be very happy living there. But if something happens to the person who actually owns the house, I could be forced to leave and then lose everything. There's a possibility though that if anything happens to the owner of that house, I may be able to take over the mortgage, but the amount that the mortgage costs is extremely expensive, I could probably afford it, but I'm not positive. So I'm not sure if it would be better for me to stay where I am and try and make repairs to this house, even though I could also possibly lose this house if anything happens to the other person or if I should go ahead and make repairs to the other house and possibly lose everything.

Supporter: After hearing about your housing options it actually seems like you're in a better place, either way, than not. Both options, whether to stay in your current situation or to move have some road bumps, but nothing too extravagant. Yes, both you may have to put money up front, but the outcome of either sound like they would be financially worthy in the end. However if you are asking my opinion, I would say the second option of moving would benefit both you and the person you could potentially help out.

full_conversation:
Seeker: I'm 51 years old and I am not close to my father. I grew up in a divorced family and my dad had custody of me. But growing up in the eighties, being a father in the eighties is a lot different than being a father in the nineties. And I was the first child. So my dad had to work two jobs and I never really got to spend much time with my dad. I spend a lot of time with my grandparents and I think of my grandfather as a dad and I regret in life later in life now that I am not close to my dad the way my, I am close to my son. When I had my son, I wanted to be a better father than what I had in the sense of being around, being there for him. As opposed to when I grew up, my dad was never around. But I also understand that he was never around because he had to work and he was providing an income and putting food on the table. So on one hand, I understand why I'm not close to him, but I also regret not being close to him.

Supporter: You were a child and a relationship requires the effort of two people. There are things your father could've done to make you feel more loved. Even though he was working, he could've at least taken a day off and I'm sure he had holidays off. It's very good that you've made an effort with your child and I'm happy you were able to learn from your experience and use it to positively change your future. I hope one day you'll talk to your dad about how you felt and maybe be able to grow closer, it's never too late. Of course only if that's what you want to do.

full_conversation:
Seeker: The complex situation that I am grappling with is that my spouse has a chronic illness which involves her being immunocompromised. Therefore, it greatly limits her exposure to the outside world. And by definition, my exposure to it as well. What I am trying to understand is to what extent can I do normal everyday things, not risky things. I'm not looking to go to busy street festivals or anything, but just to go to museums, to visit friends indoors at their houses, to go to a gymnasium, to work out. To what extent can I do that without endangering my partner? My partner is taking a very rigid approach to this, but this is uh this is a struggle for me trying to figure out how to handle this.

Supporter: I completely understand where you're coming from. I have gone through similar experiences in my life, and I can see both sides of the situation. Yes, it concerns your partner's health, but you also have to prioritize your own happiness and freedom. I believe there are steps you can take to minimize risk. Ensure that no members of a household you visit are sick, attend gym and other outings on slow days where capacity at those places are low. Things like that. Make it known to your partner that you find joy in these things, and in having your own sense of freedom. If they still don't understand, then it's something that needs to be addressed.
